column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0002] The present invention relates to structural insulated panels such as for building exterior walls, and building structures using same.
#Text=[0003] Structural insulated panels (SIPS) have been around for a number of years.
#Text=In the 1950's until about 1980, panels were made 4 feet wide and up to 12 feet long with commodity plywood and other materials.
#Text=Some of these panels have finishes that were acceptable as exterior wall surfaces.
#Text=The most common was a plywood pattern called reverse board and batten or sometimes T 1-11 ply.
#Text=The inside of that was a material such as drywall or plywood.
#Text=The center of these panels was plastic foam to complete a SIP panel.
#Text=[0004] The SIP panels discussed above were largely superseded when oriented strand board (OSB) became available in 8 foot by 24 foot sheets.
#Text=The 4 foot wide panels were too costly and inefficient to install when one big panel could replace six small 4-foot-wide panels.
#Text=However, a problem with this big 8 foot by 24 foot panel was that it did not have a finished surface on the inside nor outside, since OSB does not provide it.
#Text=Thus, the big panels were usually covered with drywall on the inside and covered with exterior siding on the outside.

#Text=Unfortunately, this process of covering inside and outside surfaces after building/wall construction is very expensive and made construction with SIPs more expensive than conventional "stick" construction.
#Text=Even though SIP construction could save 30% to 50% of the heat loss, there has been continued resistance to use the SIP systems because of costs of material versus "stick" construction.
#Text=SUMMARY OF THE PRESENT INVENTION
#Text=[0005] One aspect of the present invention is a structural insulated panel made with a foam plastic core and oriented strand board attached on either side to form board faces.
#Text=The oriented strand board faces are capped with a structural paper that provides a finished surface.
#Text=The core, OSB and structural paper are all securely bonded together.
